results.title: Waterloo farmers
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Roman Bittman, Gary Toole and Italo Costa
results.brief_description: This film juxtaposes Old Order Mennonites and New Order Mennonites. Their differing beliefs are reflected in their methods of farming. One has not changed in four hundred years; the other is up-to-date and mechanized. The film asks whether a compromise will eventually have to be reached between the two.

results.title: Waterloo bridge
results.creator_credit: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Sidney A. Franklin and Mervyn LeRoy
results.brief_description: Starring Vivian Leigh and Robert Taylor, this is a tragic tale. An army officer marries a ballerina. When he is reported missing his family ignores her and she sinks into prostitution. A ‘weepie’ which has had mixed reviews over time, but still remains very popular.

results.title: Waterloo
results.creator_credit: Australian Film Commission and Tom Zubrycki
results.brief_description: Set in Waterloo, an inner city suburb of Sydney, this film describes the bitter and drawn out struggle of a group of residents to save their suburb from slum clearance and redevelopment by state housing authorities. Making extensive use of newsreels, stills and re-enactment, “Waterloo” examines the struggle in the context of the history of Sydney’s inner city suburbs from the anti eviction campaigns of the 1930s to the rise of the resident action movement of the late 1960s. This film shows how squatting and trade union intervention eventually succeeded in forcing the government to recognise the right of the ordinary people to participate in planning decisions affecting the future of their communities. Four months after this film was first publicly screened in 1981, the residents of Waterloo won their battle. The film played a major part in that victory.

results.title: Waterloo
results.creator_credit: Filmsonor, E. Bernhard and C. de Renesse
results.brief_description: Wellington’s headquarters still stand in the peaceful village of Waterloo; Napoleon’s army tent, swords are on display in the museum where visitors are shepherded past wax figures, paintings, firearms, and even skeletons collected from the battlefields. The camera takes in the silent brooding landscape, then turns to the painted war scenes to recreate the battle.

results.title: Waterloo
results.creator_credit: Columbia Pictures, Dino De Laurentiis and Sergei Bondarchuk
results.brief_description: Napoleon’s abdication and his exile to Elba: his dramatic escape, his reunion with his devoted troops and their generals. His last, desperate bid for ultimate power and glory, so narrowly defeated on the bloody fields of Waterloo. This is a film on an epic scale with a cast to match, contributing fine portraits of great men against a magnificent backdrop of battle and bloodshed.

results.title: Waterlily
results.creator_credit: Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School, Chris McGill and Katie Wright
results.brief_description: It is Lily’s 15th birthday and she is faced with spending the day with her ridiculous and unbearable family. Until her party she escapes into her dreams of “football star”, Tony Young - the latest object of her romantic imagination. At the same time Old Hob, a permanent resident in the family hotel, is set upon finding the ‘big stream’, enlisting a skateboarding gang to form a team of water diviners which includes Jeff, who has a crush on Lily. At the climax of her day circumstances go embarrassingly and disastrously awry as Lily is trying to deal with her family and her hopeful yet unrequited love for Tony. Yet, with the help of a little magic, even under the reign of absolute chaos, something might just turn out alright for Lily.

results.title: Waterfront
results.creator_credit: Waterfront Pty Ltd, Bob Weis and Chris Thomson
results.brief_description: It is the early 1930s, facing rising unemployment, industrial unrest and increasingly bitter class divisions Australia is on the verge of a violent labour dispute. When they are ordered by the courts to take a pay cut, the already unhappy dock workers strike - effectively shutting down the Melbourne waterfront. Australia’s Prime Minister orders the strike to be broken by ‘free labourers’. Bosses respond by hiring newly arrived Italian immigrants who just want to work. When the Italian ‘scabs’ keep the docks operating, the waterfront erupts into a state of civil war. Set against this backdrop is the doomed love story of of Maxey (Jack Thompson), a happy-go-lucky wharfie and Anna (Greta Scacchi), a beautiful Italian immigrant. Against all odds and prevailing racial attitudes, their love story struggles to survive the tragic consequences of a labour war that had no victor.

results.title: Waterfowl in action
results.creator_credit: University of Minnesota. Audio-Visual Education Service
results.brief_description: Migrating waterfowl are filmed as they stop to feed and rest in the marshes near Wheaton, Minnesota. The Franklin gull, gadwall, spoonbill, green and blue winged teal, the diving ducks, blue and lesser snow geese, whistling swans and others are shown on the water and in flight. Feeding habits and identifying field marks are explained. NB: In this film waterfowl are seen as potential targets for sporting shooters and so must be conserved to keep the sport going!

results.title: Waterfowl - a resource in danger
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Peter Jones and Don Virgo
results.brief_description: The prairies are the incubators of vast numbers of Canadian waterfowl, principally ducks, but, as much land is drained and cultivated there are fewer breeding grounds. This film shows the immense flocks of birds, their habits, and their dependence on the wetlands of the prairies. How to maintain living space for the ducks without having them pose a threat to farmer’s grainfields is a problem being studied by the Canadian Wildlife Service.

results.title: Waterfall polyptych
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Malcolm Otton and David Muir
results.brief_description:
Episode number 26 of Series “The Australian eye V”.
The four large panels that make up “Waterfall polyptych” can be seen as a climax to the many years that Fred Williams has spent in developing his own austere and highly personal language of painterly forms with which to interpret the Australian landscape. The artist describes the importance to him of recording first impressions in front of the subject and the four preliminary panels are studied in relation to the final work. Suitable for middle and upper secondary level.
